Award.AwardTitle: National Ecological Observatory Network: Construction and Transition
Award.AbstractNarration:
The biosphere is one of the planet's most complex systems with countless internal processes and interactions with the earth's physical processes and systems. It is imperative that we understand how the biosphere is responding to and affecting earth's physical systems, yet our understanding of the biosphere does not match our increasingly sophisticated understanding of the earth's physical and chemical systems at regional, continental, and global scales. The National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) is designed to understand and predict: (1) how ecosystems work and respond to changes, especially at large scales; (2) how ecosystem processes feed back to alter earth system processes, including climate and hydrology; and (3) the implications of these processes and feedbacks for human endeavors. NEON will enable research on the impacts of climate and land use change, unsustainable water use, and invasive species on the Nation's living ecosystems at the temporal and spatial scales that are relevant to human well-being. NEON will be the first research platform and the only national experimental facility specifically designed to enable research to answer continental-scale questions on causes of and responses to environmental change and the mechanisms involved in observed changes. NEON will be the first experimental facility to collect consistent and standardized biological measurements across nationwide sites and to make the data available in close to real-time.

This award provides Major Research Equipment and Facility Construction funds to construct NEON. Funds are provided to deploy geographically distributed field and lab infrastructure networked via cybertechnology to form an integrated research platform. Cutting-edge sensor networks, instrumentation, experimental infrastructure, cyberinfrastructure, support facilities including towers and board walks, and biological sampling plots will be deployed in the continental US, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and Alaska. Three airborne remote sensing systems and mobile laboratories will be constructed. Funds are provided for central technical, cyberinfrastructure, and project management facilities and support staff. Resources are provided to develop the NEON data products and to integrate federal agency operational data resources. Funds are provided to develop NEON's education and outreach portals and staff training programs. The data from these resources will be linked to computational, analytical, and modeling capabilities to create NEON's integrated infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: The National Science Foundation's (NSF) National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) is a continental-scale infrastructure of field sites identified and designed by the scientific research community to collect and provide over 180 high quality, open access data products from across the United States that characterize and quantify our nation's ecosystems. As a result, NEON will generate an unprecedented amount of data on interactions between ecosystem components across the continent and over the course of a human generation.

Battelle began operating NEON on behalf of the NSF in 2016 and currently employs over 500 staff annually across the Observatory. NEON's 81 field sites (47 terrestrial and 34 aquatic) are located in 24 states, including Alaska and Hawaii, as well as Puerto Rico. These sites were strategically selected to represent our nation's varied regions of vegetation, landforms, climate and ecosystem performance.

The standardized data produced by NEON enables an unmatched level of scientific analysis of the impacts of large-scale environmental changes on our ability to sustainably meet society's food and water security needs, and address linkages to public health. As the largest independent non-profit R&D company in the world, Battelle's mission of applying science and technology for societal benefit is uniquely suited to achieving NEON's objectives.

NEON data and resources are freely available to enable researchers, students and interested parties across the globe to tackle scientific questions at scales not accessible to previous generations of ecologists. This democratization of data will help transform ecology from a principally observational science to a predictive one.

As more data have become available from NEON, the amount of data downloaded by the research community is continuously increasing.

Informing Policy: The insights gleaned from NEON may inform decisions at the national and community levels that will impact natural resource management and human well-being for generations. Examples include:

  • Infectious Disease: NEON provides data on the distribution and disease load of ticks, mosquitoes and small mammals, all carriers of disease that impact human health. NEON will provide an inventory of samples and information at the regional and local levels over decades for analysis, enabling predictive modeling of future disease distribution.
  • Ecological Forecasting: NEON's consistent data collection procedures across the continent enables predictive modeling to better understand 1) the ecological impacts of natural hazards such as wildfires, floods, and hurricanes; and 2) the potential migration patterns of disease vectors (such as ticks) that impact human and livestock health, as well as natural pests (such as pine beetles) that can have devastating impacts on forest health. With this information, policy makers and landowners can make better informed decisions about management of environmental resources.
  • Surface-Atmosphere Exchange (Flux): micrometeorological data collected by NEON flux towers yield over 19 eddy covariance data products. By combining these data with information about the speed and direction of the air currents themselves, we can get a picture of how energy, water and gases are flowing into and out of the atmospheric boundary layer. Weather and climate conditions, along with seasonally changing biological and biogeochemical processes, are important drivers and indicators of terrestrial and aquatic ecosystem function.
  • Biomass Changes and Canopy Chemistry: the NEON Airborne Observation Platform (AOP) addresses a critical hole in ecological data collection by providing data for scientists to monitor changes in vegetation patterns and canopy chemistry on a continental scale over an extended time period. These data will provide new insights into how invasive species are spreading over time and how changes in climate and land use impact forest health and the ability of forests to sequester carbon. These data may also be combined with field-based measurements or satellite data to enable scientific study of continental-scale patterns and processes.

Funding Background: The NEON program is the first life science project to be constructed solely with NSF Major Research Equipment and Facilities Construction (MREFC) funding. Construction of NEON began in 2011, and early operations of the Observatory began in 2014. Congress invested approximately $700 million to construct and operate NEON through 2019.

Additional Information and access to all NEON Data Products is available at neonscience.org. Many informative videos are available to help the public, decision makers, and researchers understand and utilize NEON data. Please see the NEON web site for the latest information, including these and other short videos: 

Open Data to Understand our Changing Ecosystems,

Mapping the Invisible: Introduction to the AOP Spectral Remote Sensing.
